TEI.2.document_title: Stephen F Austin to Josiah H Bell, 02-24-1829

barker_notes.barker_summary: Austin to Josiah H. Bell, February 24, 1829. Political news from Mexico. Sees prospect of amending Federal constitution to permit religious toleration; thinks household worship will cause no trouble now, but wants no Methodist excitement. Plans for an academy at San Felipe.
barker_notes.barker_footnotes: Decree No. 70, Jan. 13, 1829. See Gammel, Laws of Texas, I, 120. See H. H. Bancroft, History of Mexico, V, 35-40. The hope was probably based mainly on the fact that the clergy had almost unanimously opposed Guerrero, who was now in the saddle.
barker_notes.barker_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1919: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1924), 3 vols., Vol 1, Part 2, pp. 172-174

text.body:
*div1 type="summary"* *p*Austin to Josiah H. Bell, February 24, 1829. Political news from Mexico. Sees prospect of amending Federal constitution to permit religious toleration; thinks household worship will cause no trouble now, but wants no Methodist excitement. Plans for an academy at San Felipe.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p**date_mentioned n="02-24-1829">Feb 24 1829*/date_mentioned**/p* *p*Dr Sir.*/p*
*p*The mail has this moment arrived—the subject of *location_mentioned*foriegn */location_mentioned*debts is finally settled as you will see by the enclosed law which speaks for itself and needs no explanation—it is very full— The difficulties in *location_mentioned*Mexico */location_mentioned*are all settled. *person_mentioned*Guerrero is the President */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*Bustamante the vice President*/person_mentioned*— *person_mentioned*Pedrasa*/person_mentioned*'s election was set aside by *person_mentioned*congress */person_mentioned*in the manner prescribed by the constitution on the ground of fraud and corruption and *person_mentioned*congress */person_mentioned*then proceeded to elect from the other persons who stood highest in the list, and at the first vote *person_mentioned*Guerrero */person_mentioned*recd. 15 *location_mentioned*States */location_mentioned*and Bustamte *person_mentioned**/person_mentioned*13—there are 19 *location_mentioned*states */location_mentioned*in all so that this great question is now finally settled in a legal and constitutional manner and tranquility is fully restored*/p*
*p*The prospect of a change in the national constitution so as to strike out the restriction on Religious toleration is so great and brightening so rapidly that I have no longer any doubts that it must and will take place, and under this belief I am of opinion that no evils will arise from *person_mentioned*family */person_mentioned*or *person_mentioned*neighborhood */person_mentioned*worship, or from the delivery of moral lectures, provided it is not done in a way to make a noise about public preaching So as not to start excited *person_mentioned*methodist preachers*/person_mentioned*, for I do say that in some instances they are too, fanatic, too violent and too noisy,— Moral instruction delivered in that pure, chaste and dignified language and manner with which such instruction ought to be imparted to rational beings, will certainly not be objected to by the Govt on the contrary it will be highly approved of. I give this as my opinion*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*Mr Pilgrim*/person_mentioned* proposes to teach *location_mentioned*school */location_mentioned*I am pleased with him so far as I have been able to judge— My opinion on this subject is that we should all unite with a view of establishing a permanent *location_mentioned*Academy */location_mentioned*at this place—*/p*
*p*If we now commence on this basis, I have no doubt of succeeding, and if the subject is pushed and properly laid before the Govt. I have no doubt of obtaining a liberal endowment of funds— I fear that a division in the minds of the people as to where the *location_mentioned*Academy */location_mentioned*ought to be located would totally defeat the object, and for this reason I am in favor of engaging *person_mentioned*Mr Pilgrim*/person_mentioned* to establish a *location_mentioned*School */location_mentioned*here permanently and that measures be adopted without delay to raise funds by subscription for a suitable *location_mentioned*house*/location_mentioned*, large enough to accommodate about 100 *person_mentioned*scholars*/person_mentioned*— I have drawn a plan which I send you*/p*
*p*This subject is a very important one, it has always been a favorite one with me, and I think an effort should be now made to get the *location_mentioned*school */location_mentioned*under way, it can be added to afterwards—in fact it will naturally increase as its reputation becomes known and I fear that if the present opportunity passes of geting a permanent *person_mentioned*teacher */person_mentioned* another may not o[ffer so] on. I will however unite in support of any general plan to establish *location_mentioned*Schools*/location_mentioned*, which will do the most public good—*/p*
*p*Please present my best respects to *person_mentioned*Mrs Bell*/person_mentioned*. *person_mentioned*Mrs Powel*/person_mentioned* *person_mentioned*Dr. Wells*/person_mentioned* and *person_mentioned*family */person_mentioned*etc*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*S. F. Austin */person_mentioned* [Rubric]*/p*
*p*The subject of preaching must be managed with prudence, for I do assure you that it will not do to have the *person_mentioned*Methodist */person_mentioned*excitement raised in this *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*— All this is for your eye, and your confidential *person_mentioned*friends*/person_mentioned*, and not for the public indiscriminately*/p* *p*[Addressed:] *person_mentioned*J.H.Bell*/person_mentioned**/p*
*/div1*
